children.value: Reach out to thousands of boilerplate fans, indiehackers, developers, and creators who visit and explore MintedDirectory every month. By advertising your service or product here, you‚Äôll be able to connect directly with this engaged audience. üöÄ

Paid listings  to secure a spot in our directory by paying a fee. These listings gain more exposure than free listings, ensuring that businesses are prominently displayed to potential customers. By upgrading to a paid listing, you increase the chances of being noticed in a competitive space.

Even in free directories, we offer featured or boosted listings. Businesses can pay for a premium position at the top of the directory, ensuring maximum visibility. Featured listings are highlighted to stand out, making it easier for potential customers to find and engage with businesses.
Here‚Äôs an example of how featured listings will look to Minted Directory visitors:
Sponsors can place their brand on the homepage gaining exposure to our growing audience. This is an excellent option for businesses looking to build brand awareness and connect with our community.

You can use multiple consecutive newline characters (
) to create extra spacing between sections in a markdown document. However, if you need to ensure that extra newlines are not collapsed, you can use as many HTML
spaces at the end of your paragraph to force a soft linebreak.
element is for creating a "thematic break" between paragraph-level elements. In markdown, you can use of the following for this purpose:

children.value: Autolinks are absolute URIs and email addresses inside
. They are parsed as links, where the URI or email address itself is used as the link's label.

props.code: <http://foo.bar.baz>

children.value: URIs or email addresses that are not wrapped in angle brackets are not recognized as valid autolinks by markdown parsers.

props.code: [Assemble](http://assemble.io)

Named anchors enable you to jump to the specified anchor point on the same page. For example, each of these chapters:

props.code:
# Table of Contents
  * [Chapter 1](#chapter-1)
  * [Chapter 2](#chapter-2)
  * [Chapter 3](#chapter-3)
## Chapter 1 Content for chapter one. ## Chapter 2 Content for chapter one. ## Chapter 3 Content for chapter one.

children.value: ## Chapter 1 Content for chapter one. ## Chapter 2 Content for chapter one. ## Chapter 3 Content for chapter one.
Note that placement of achors is arbitrary, you can put them anywhere you want, not just in headings. This makes adding cross-references easy when writing markdown.
Images have a similar syntax to links but include a preceding exclamation point.

children.value: Tables are created by adding pipes as dividers between each cell, and by adding a line of dashes (also separated by bars) beneath the header
pipes do not need to be vertically aligned.
pipes on the left and right sides of the table are sometimes optional
three or more dashes must be used for each cell in the separator row

props.code:

| ------ | ----------- |

| engine | engine to be used for processing templates. Handlebars is the default. |
| ext    | extension to be used for dest files. |

Three consecutive backticks, referred to as "code fences", are used to denote multiple lines of code:
Appears like this when viewed in a browser:

props.code: Example text here...

children.value: You may also indent several lines of code by at least four spaces, but this is not recommended as it is harder to read, harder to maintain, and doesn't support syntax highlighting.

    line 2 of code
    line 3 of code

To activate the correct styling for the language inside the code block, simply add the file extension of the language you want to use directly after the first code "fence":

Front matter allows you to insert metadata to your markdown document. The front matter block must be written in the first line before everything else, like in the examples below.
YAML front matter blocks are identified by an opening and closing

props.code:
---
title: YAML front matter example
key: value
---

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, graecis denique ei vel, at duo primis mandamus.

children.value:

title: YAML front matter example
key: value
---

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, graecis denique ei vel, at duo primis mandamus.
TOML front matter blocks are identified by an opening and closing

props.code:
+++
title = "YAML front matter example"
key = "value"
+++

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, graecis denique ei vel, at duo primis mandamus.

props.code: For example, to show $\alpha \beta \gamma$ inline with other text, just wrap it in dollar signs.

Two consecutive dollar signs are used to denote multiple lines of math formulas:

props.code:
$$
R_x=\begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 & 0\\
0 & cos(a) & -sin(a) & 0\\
0 & sin(a) & cos(a) & 0\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

or

$$
m=\frac{b_y-a_y}{b_x-a_x}
$$

children.value:
$$
R_x=\begin{pmatrix}
1 & 0 & 0 & 0\\
0 & cos(a) & -sin(a) & 0\\
0 & sin(a) & cos(a) & 0\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 1
\end{pmatrix}
$$

or

$$
m=\frac{b_y-a_y}{b_x-a_x}

MarkText support class, flow chart, gantt and sequence diagrams powered by flowchart.js, mermaid and Vega-Lite.
blocks with special language identifiers are used for diagrams.

## Vega-lite diagram

Please see [introduction to Vega-Lite](https://vega.github.io/vega-lite/tutorials/getting_started.html) for details.

```vega-lite
{
  "data": {
    "values": [
      {"a": "C", "b": 2}, {"a": "C", "b": 7}, {"a": "C", "b": 4},
      {"a": "D", "b": 1}, {"a": "D", "b": 2}, {"a": "D", "b": 6},
      {"a": "E", "b": 8}, {"a": "E", "b": 4}, {"a": "E", "b": 7}
    ]
  },
  "mark": "point",
  "encoding": {
    "x": {"field": "a", "type": "nominal"},
    "y": {"field": "b", "type": "quantitative"}
  }
}
```

## Flowchart

```flowchart
st=>start: Start|past
e=>end: End|future
op1=>operation: My Operation|past
op2=>operation: Stuff|current
sub1=>subroutine: My Subroutine|invalid
cond=>condition: Yes
or No?|approved:>http://www.google.com
c2=>condition: Good idea|rejected
io=>inputoutput: catch something...|future

st->op1(right)->cond
cond(yes, right)->c2
cond(no)->sub1(left)->op1
c2(yes)->io->e
c2(no)->op2->e
```

## Sequence diagram

```sequence
Title: Here is a title
A->B: Normal line
B-->C: Dashed line
C->>D: Open arrow
D-->>A: Dashed open arrow
```

## Flowchart

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A-->B;
    A-->C;
    B-->D;
    C-->D;
```

## Sequence diagram

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant Alice
    participant Bob
    Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you?
    loop Healthcheck
        John->>John: Fight against hypochondria
    end
    Note right of John: Some note
    John-->>Alice: Great!
    John->>Bob: How about you?
    Bob-->>John: Jolly good!
```

## Gantt diagram

```mermaid
gantt
dateFormat  YYYY-MM-DD
title Adding GANTT diagram to mermaid
excludes weekdays 2014-01-10

section A section
Completed task            :done,    des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08
Active task               :active,  des2, 2014-01-09, 3d
Future task               :         des3, after des2, 5d
Future task2               :         des4, after des3, 5d
```

## Class diagram (experimental)

```mermaid
classDiagram
Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool
Class03 *-- Class04
Class05 o-- Class06
Class07 .. Class08
Class09 --> C2 : Where am i?
Class09 --* C3
Class09 --|> Class07
Class07 : equals()
Class07 : Object[] elementData
Class01 : size()
Class01 : int chimp
Class01 : int gorilla
Class08 <--> C2: Cool label
```
